text: just a week ago this was an empty field
now it's home to hundreds fleeing the
battles of Ramadi joining many thousands
uprooted by the violence across Iraq
Puzzle arrived here with her family or
what's left of it as they were fleeing a
bomb went off as those two teenage
sisters were killed she and her brother
were hit by the shrapnel the family had
already lost one of its sons to the
self-styled Islamic state they took my
son and held him for a year
accusing him of being an alarmist by
then they came and said we've killed him
and don't even ask about him or you'll
be in trouble and life was terrible the
children were living in fear the dogs
were living better than us the camps not
far from the front line with the city of
Fallujah
it's a stronghold of the Sunnis under
Saddam Hussein they virtually ruled Iraq
now is is in control they're cashing in
on Sunni resentment against the shear
dominated government the battle for
Fallujah is clearly coming up very soon
but as the government forces push harder
against is the militants one thing is
becoming very clear this is not a war
that can be won by military means alone
they have to win back the Sunni
community whose alienation from the
Baghdad government gave is the militants
fertile soil in which to take root most
of the eius fighters in Fallujah and
elsewhere are believed to be Iraqis not
outsiders but here Sunni tribes have
taken up arms against is everybody's
been harmed by is houses and mosques
destroyed people killed wounded
displaced they arrived saying we have
come to help you to defend you but now
they have shown their true colors and
people are cursing is because they have
seen its reality
this is what is left behind in Ramadi
the Army's almost won the fight here but
there's a long way to go before is is
driven out of the huge Anbar province
history has shown that if the government
loses the battle for Sunni hearts and
minds it could lose all this all over
again Jim your BBC news
Alan Barr
